newsitem.title: UK: FINE AIR PLANE INSURED FOR $10 MLN - MARKET.
newsitem.headline: FINE AIR PLANE INSURED FOR $10 MLN - MARKET.

text.p: A Fine Air DC-8-61F cargo plane which crashed yesterday was insured for $10 million, London insurance market sources told Reuters on Friday.
The jet crashed seconds after take-off from Miami International Airport and has been declared a total loss, insurers said.
All four crew members are presumed dead after the plane plummeted to the ground, skidded across a six-lane road and crashed into the parking lot of a shopping mall.
The aircraft, registration number N27UA, was built in 1968. The UK broker was C.E. Heath.
The flaming wreckage set fire to cars, trucks and parts of buildings, sending orange fireballs and dense clouds of black smoke into the air.
This brings to six the number of accidents involving large aircraft in little over a week and comes just two days after a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 crashed on Guam with heavy loss of life.
Hull losses alone from these accidents are estimated to cost insurers close to $200 million, with no clear estimate yet on liability claims.
The KAL aircraft was insured for around $60 million, while a Federal Express freighter which crashed at Newark was insured for $115 million, making it the third most costly hull loss ever.
Three other passenger aircraft have also been damaged or destroyed in the last week, but none is expected to lead to a large insurance claim.
Two were total losses -- An ATR-42 which crashed at Florence airport and was insured for $14.5 million and an Air Afrique Boeing 737 insured for $3.0 million.
A British Aerospace ATP airliner was damaged when it landed on two wheels at Manchester airport. No loss estimate is available yet on this aircraft.
